bibl.title: Tradition and Innovation in the Burial Practices of Roman Egypt.

series.title: Culture and History of the Ancient Near East.

bibl.note: In Roman Egypt, some burial practices and funerary imagery either stayed the same, or followed a new line of development linked to the past. On the other end, there are some genuine innovations, like the use of naturalistic portraiture. The combination of ancient and modern, timeless and timely, is responsible for evocative creations.

bibl.seg: RIGGS Christina, Tradition and Innovation in the Burial Practices of Roman Egypt.

Katja LEMBKE, Martina MINAS-NERPEL and Stefan PFEIFFER (Edd.), Tradition and Transformation: Egypt under Roman Rule. Proceedings of the International Conference, Hildesheim, Roemer- and Pelizaeus-Museum, 3-6 July 2008 = Culture and History of the Ancient Near East. 41 (Leiden, 2010) pp. 343-356, 4 figg.

In Roman Egypt, some burial practices and funerary imagery either stayed the same, or followed a new line of development linked to the past. On the other end, there are some genuine innovations, like the use of naturalistic portraiture. The combination of ancient and modern, timeless and timely, is responsible for evocative creations.
